verses.text: Blessed is the man who has not sinned with his mouth, and who has not been pierced by the pain of sin.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the virtue of controlling one's speech, echoed in James's teaching about the tongue. Highlights the spiritual discipline of purity in words, laying foundation for holiness.

verses.text: Blessed is he whose heart does not condemn him, and who has not lost hope in the Lord.
verses.comment: This links the blessing to a clear conscience, paralleling the assurance John writes about. The importance of interior peace and hope in God is a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: Riches are not fitting for a greedy person; and what use is money to a miser?
verses.comment: Warnings against greed are rooted throughout Scripture, such as Jesus's teaching against serving money. Material blessings are to be stewarded, not hoarded.

verses.text: What he denies himself, others will enjoy. He will consume his own fortune to no profit.
verses.comment: The futility of selfish accumulation is highlighted here, reminiscent of Jesus’s warning to the rich fool. Temporal wealth is passing; generosity yields lasting reward.

verses.text: He who is evil to himself, to whom will he be good? He does not enjoy his own riches.
verses.comment: Echoing the moral principle that self-care enables care for others, this anticipates Christ’s call to love one's neighbor as oneself.

verses.text: No one is worse than the one who is stingy to himself, and this is how his wickedness will be repaid.
verses.comment: The consequences of self-centeredness are both spiritual and practical, anticipating the retribution principle found in the Gospels.

verses.text: If he does good, he does it unwillingly, and in the end he reveals his own wickedness.
verses.comment: Contrast with Paul’s teaching that giving should be cheerful. True virtue arises from joy and love, not compulsion.

verses.text: The eye of the envious person is greedy for bread and does not appreciate anyone at his table.
verses.comment: Envy and greed corrupt social fellowship. Sharing with others is a sign of spiritual health, reflective of the table fellowship Christ emphasizes.

verses.text: He envies the prosperity of others, and his own famine cannot be healed.
verses.comment: Envy dries up both material and spiritual blessing, as seen in Psalm 73. True satisfaction is found in God.

verses.text: An evil eye grudges bread, and is lacking at his own table.
verses.comment: The 'evil eye' represents stinginess and spiritual poverty, paralleling Jesus’s teaching on the eye as the lamp of the body.

verses.text: My son, treat yourself well, according to what you have, and bring offerings to the Lord worthy of you.
verses.comment: Balancing self-care and piety, this verse suggests the goodness of celebrating God's gifts and bringing fitting offerings, echoed in Proverbs.

verses.text: Remember that death does not delay, and the covenant of the grave has not been shown to you.
verses.comment: Warns of the certainty of death and judgment, paralleling Hebrews 9. Urges reflection on mortality and the proper use of temporal blessings.

verses.text: Do good to your friend before you die, and according to your ability, reach out and give to the poor.
verses.comment: Favors works of mercy, matching Christ’s exhortation to care for the needy. Generosity is a mark of God’s people.

verses.text: Do not deprive yourself of a good day, and do not withhold your share of rightful enjoyment.
verses.comment: Echoing wisdom literature, affirms legitimate enjoyment of creation’s gifts as part of God’s plan.

verses.text: Will you not leave your achievements to others, and your hard-earned wealth to those who come after you?
verses.comment: Reminds of the transience of worldly possessions, encouraging wise stewardship and a spiritual legacy.

verses.text: Give, take, and rejoice, for no one can seek pleasure in the grave.
verses.comment: The brevity of life compels joy and generosity. Wisdom literature often urges enjoyment of God’s gifts in this life.

verses.text: All flesh grows old like a garment; the covenant from the beginning is: 'You must die.'
verses.comment: Refers to mortality decreed after the Fall. The inevitability of death underscores the urgency for spiritual readiness.

verses.text: Like flourishing leaves on a great tree—some fall and others grow—such are the generations of flesh and blood: one dies, another blossoms.
verses.comment: Life’s cycles mirror the passing of generations, calling us to eternal perspective amidst temporal change.

verses.text: Everything made will decay and pass away; and the person who pleases the Lord receives a lasting name.
verses.comment: The Scripture stresses the value of pleasing God, providing assurance of a spiritual legacy that surpasses earthly things.

verses.text: Blessed is the man who meditates on wisdom, and who considers her in his heart,
verses.comment: Meditation on wisdom aligns closely with the biblical practice of pondering God's law. Wisdom is personified, foreshadowing the fulfillment of wisdom in Christ (cf. 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: who reflects on her ways in his heart and ponders her secrets.
verses.comment: This encourages not just outward obedience but heartfelt reflection, key to spiritual growth and discernment.

verses.text: He pursues her like a hunter and lies in wait by her path.
verses.comment: Depicts the active searching for wisdom, echoing Proverbs’ counsel to seek wisdom with diligence.

verses.text: He looks in at her windows and listens at her doors.
verses.comment: Expresses earnest longing for wisdom, involving both observation and readiness to learn.

verses.text: He lodges close to her house and fixes his pegs in her walls.
verses.comment: The image of ‘dwelling’ with wisdom alludes to God’s presence, and hints at the scriptural theme of abiding in God's ways.

verses.text: He sets up his tent beside her and dwells in a good place to find her.
verses.comment: Nearness to wisdom brings blessing; spiritually, this hints at the intimacy of abiding with God’s wisdom and, in Christian interpretation, abiding in Christ.

verses.text: He places his children under her shelter and finds rest under her branches.
verses.comment: Wisdom offers safety and rest, carrying a subtle allusion to Christ’s parable of the mustard seed—where the kingdom offers shelter to all.

verses.text: By wisdom, he is protected from the heat, and lives in her glory.
verses.comment: Wisdom provides protection, comfort, and honor—echoing Old Testament themes of God as shelter. In Christian tradition, wisdom is fulfilled in union with God’s revelation through Christ.
